Judul: SURROGATE AND MACHINE LEARNING MODELS FOR MULTI-POINT TURBOMACHINE FAN BLADE DESIGN PARAMETERS
Abstrak:
Modern turbomachine blade shape designs typically are parameterized by a set of
high-dimensional design variables ranging from 20 to 250 dimensions. These design
parameters are useful for aerodynamic, structural and manufacturing design
purposes. But it is acknowledged that the latter has a very high cost in the design
process and lacks flexibility as it demands high computational resources. Nowadays,
surrogate models are considered as an important role in parametric studies
such as optimization, design exploration, and sensitivity analysis that used to be
challenging and computationally exhaustive. By utilizing the so-called black box
model as where the prediction takes place surrogate models were approved as a
robust method in order to give lower cost and broader flexibility in parametric
studies. In this undergraduate thesis, the performance of three surrogate models
are presented and compared, such as; Kriging, Support Vector Regression (SVR),
and Gradient Boosting Regression (GBR), with additional Linear Regression as a
benchmark for analyzing the data set. The performance metrics are compared in
Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) and R-squared (R2) in boxplots with 30 iterations.
The presented RMSE is normalized with Interquartile Range (IQR) and
R2 is presented in 1  R2 for better visualization for comparison purposes. From
all of the results, Kriging proves as the best model with the most desirable prediction
results based on the evaluation metrics with a trade off of computationally
exhaustive resources. SVR comes second with a decent results and curiously overfitting
tendency towards large training data points. Lastly, GBR fails to present
exciting results as it gives relatively poor results in general even compared to the
benchmark of Linear Regression.
Kontributor / Dosen Pembimbing: Pramudita Satria Palar, S.T., M.T., Ph.D.
